arm_group.description: The subjects will be exposed to a cold (~ 12° C) water immersion tub at the umbilical level for 20 minutes.
The subjects will be exposed to a non-cold (~ 26° C) water immersion tub at the umbilical level for 20 minutes.

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine the immediate effects of cryotherapy on the lower
      extremity biomechanics during running.

clinical_study.brief_title: Cryotherapy and Joint Biomechanics During Running

detailed_description.textblock:
Cryotherapy or cold therapy has widely been used as a treatment modality in both acute and
      chronic injuries. It is believe that the application of cryotherapy can help to decrease
      pain, muscle soreness, soft tissue swelling, and cause vasoconstriction of blood vessels
      reducing heat loss. The nerve conduction velocity and muscle-spindle firing rate also
      decreases with cryotherapy, which results in changes in proprioception acuity. Cryotherapy
      has also been used prior to exercise (pre-cooling) to improve endurance activities. However,
      given the possible detrimental effects of cryotherapy on proprioception acuity, the use of
      this treatment modality prior to exercise could pose an increased risk of musculoskeletal
      injury. The effects of cryotherapy on lower extremity biomechanics during athletic movements
      is poorly understood despite the wide use among physiotherapists, athletic therapists and
      clinicians. Therefore, the purpose of this investigation is to determine the effects of cold
      water immersion on lower extremity biomechanics during running. The investigators
      hypothesize that cryotherapy as a form of treatment can increase the load in the lower
      extremity joint during gait biomechanics.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  males or females (18 - 40 yrs)

          -  no injuries of the lower extremity in the past 6 months prior to participation

          -  recreationally active

          -  in good health upon entry into the study

          -  willing to volunteer for the present project.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  lower extremity injury within the last 6 months

          -  circulatory, vestibular or any contradiction to cryotherapy including Raynaud's
             disease

intervention.description: The subjects will be exposed to a cold (~ 12° C) water immersion tub at the umbilical level for 20 minutes.
The subjects will be exposed to a non-cold (~ 26° C) water immersion tub at the umbilical level for 20 minutes.

facility.name: Human Performance Laboratory, University of Calgary

clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Cryotherapy on Lower Extremity Joint Biomechanics During Running in Healthy Adults

oversight_info.authority: Canada: Canadian Institutes of Health Research

primary_outcome.description: Knee frontal plane loading will be calculated using inverse dynamics based on the ground reaction force data from a force plate and with kinematic data recorded by high speed cameras. Kinematics and kinetics data will be taken during running at 4m/s from each participant prior and after the intervention.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Investigator), Primary Purpose: Basic Science
